Each end device nğ‘›n is associated with a dataset ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n}.
Each element diâˆˆğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›d_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{n} of a dataset, called a training sample, is represented via a feature vector xisubscriptxğ‘–\textbf{x}_{i} and a label yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} for the ML task of interest. For example, in image classification, ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i} may be the RGB colors of all pixels in the image, and yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} may be the identity of the person in the image sample. The goal of the ML task is to learn the parameters ğ°âˆˆâ„Mğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘€\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} of a particular Mğ‘€M-dimensional model (e.g., an SVM or a neural network) that are expected to maximize the accuracy in mapping from ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i} to yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} across any sample in the network. The model is associated with a loss f~â€‹(w,xi,yi)~ğ‘“wsubscriptxğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\widetilde{f}(\textbf{w},\textbf{x}_{i},y_{i}), referred to as f~iâ€‹(w)subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–w\widetilde{f}_{i}(\textbf{w})
for brevity, that quantifies the error of parameter realization ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} on disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}. We refer to Table 1 inÂ [19] for a list of common ML loss functions.

In LUT clusters, devices leverage D2D communications to obtain an approximate value of the average of their parameters. A basic approach would be to implement a message passing algorithm where nodes exchange parameters with their neighbors until each node in the cluster has all parameters stored locally. Each node can then readily calculate the aggregated value, and one of them can be sampled by the parent node. Collecting a table of parameters at each node may not be feasible, however, given how large these vectors can be for contemporary ML models, as discussed in Sec.Â II-B. Instead, we desire a technique that (i) does not require any node to store a table of all model parameters in the cluster, (ii) can be implemented in a distributed manner via D2D, and (iii) is generalizable across different network layers. In the following, we leverage distributed average consensus methods for this.

Fig.Â 8 depicts the result for the case where local datasets are i.i.d., with the values of {Ïƒj}j=1|â„’|superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘—1â„’\{\sigma_{j}\}_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{L}|} depicted. In the figures, Î¸(k)Â¯Â¯superscriptğœƒğ‘˜\overline{\theta^{(k)}} denotes the average number of D2D rounds employed by clusters over all the network layers at global iteration kğ‘˜k, and Î¸Lj(k)Â¯Â¯subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\overline{\theta^{(k)}_{{L}_{j}}} denotes the average number of D2D rounds at iteration kğ‘˜k in layer Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—{{L}_{j}}. We observe that (i) the D2D rounds performed in the network is tapered through time (subplot c), and (ii) the D2D rounds performed at different network layers is tapered through space, where higher layers of the network perform fewer rounds (subplots d-f). We perform the same experiment with non-i.i.d datasets across the nodes in Fig.Â 8. Comparing Fig.Â 8 toÂ 8, it can be observed that non-i.i.d. introduces oscillations on the number of D2D performed at different network layers, and the smaller values of D2D control parameters result in larger numbers of D2D rounds which leads to more stable training.
We summarize the simulation parameters in TableÂ I.

In LUT clusters, devices leverage D2D communications to obtain an approximate value of the average of their parameters. In the figures, Î¸(k)Â¯Â¯superscriptğœƒğ‘˜\overline{\theta^{(k)}} denotes the average number of D2D rounds employed by clusters over all the network layers at global iteration kğ‘˜k, and Î¸Lj(k)Â¯Â¯subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\overline{\theta^{(k)}_{{L}_{j}}} denotes the average number of D2D rounds at iteration kğ‘˜k in layer Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—{{L}_{j}}. We observe that (i) the D2D rounds performed in the network is tapered through time (subplot c), and (ii) the D2D rounds performed at different network layers is tapered through space, where higher layers of the network perform fewer rounds (subplots d-f). We perform the same experiment with non-i.i.d datasets across the nodes in Fig.Â 8. Comparing Fig.Â 8 toÂ 8, it can be observed that non-i.i.d. introduces oscillations on the number of D2D performed at different network layers, and the smaller values of D2D control parameters result in larger numbers of D2D rounds which leads to more stable training.
We summarize the simulation parameters in TableÂ I.

Each end device nğ‘›n is associated with a dataset ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n}.
Each element diâˆˆğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›d_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{n} of a dataset, called a training sample, is represented via a feature vector xisubscriptxğ‘–\textbf{x}_{i} and a label yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} for the ML task of interest. For example, in image classification, ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i} may be the RGB colors of all pixels in the image, and yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} may be the identity of the person in the image sample. The goal of the ML task is to learn the parameters ğ°âˆˆâ„Mğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘€\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} of a particular Mğ‘€M-dimensional model (e.g., an SVM or a neural network) that are expected to maximize the accuracy in mapping from ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i} to yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} across any sample in the network. The model is associated with a loss f~â€‹(w,xi,yi)~ğ‘“wsubscriptxğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\widetilde{f}(\textbf{w},\textbf{x}_{i},y_{i}), referred to as f~iâ€‹(w)subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–w\widetilde{f}_{i}(\textbf{w})
for brevity, that quantifies the error of parameter realization ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} on disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}. We refer to Table 1 inÂ [19] for a list of common ML loss functions.

In LUT clusters, devices leverage D2D communications to obtain an approximate value of the average of their parameters. A basic approach would be to implement a message passing algorithm where nodes exchange parameters with their neighbors until each node in the cluster has all parameters stored locally. Each node can then readily calculate the aggregated value, and one of them can be sampled by the parent node. Collecting a table of parameters at each node may not be feasible, however, given how large these vectors can be for contemporary ML models, as discussed in Sec.Â II-B. Instead, we desire a technique that (i) does not require any node to store a table of all model parameters in the cluster, (ii) can be implemented in a distributed manner via D2D, and (iii) is generalizable across different network layers. In the following, we leverage distributed average consensus methods for this.

Fig.Â 8 depicts the result for the case where local datasets are i.i.d., with the values of {Ïƒj}j=1|â„’|superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘—1â„’\{\sigma_{j}\}_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{L}|} depicted. In the figures, Î¸(k)Â¯Â¯superscriptğœƒğ‘˜\overline{\theta^{(k)}} denotes the average number of D2D rounds employed by clusters over all the network layers at global iteration kğ‘˜k, and Î¸Lj(k)Â¯Â¯subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\overline{\theta^{(k)}_{{L}_{j}}} denotes the average number of D2D rounds at iteration kğ‘˜k in layer Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—{{L}_{j}}. We observe that (i) the D2D rounds performed in the network is tapered through time (subplot c), and (ii) the D2D rounds performed at different network layers is tapered through space, where higher layers of the network perform fewer rounds (subplots d-f). We perform the same experiment with non-i.i.d datasets across the nodes in Fig.Â 8. Comparing Fig.Â 8 toÂ 8, it can be observed that non-i.i.d. introduces oscillations on the number of D2D performed at different network layers, and the smaller values of D2D control parameters result in larger numbers of D2D rounds which leads to more stable training.
